Aired 6-6:30a ET2020-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:59ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTBrent Schutte, Mitch Roschelle, Joe Concha, Buddy Carter, Jonathan Ward, Joe ConchaNEWSFinancial071501cb.231Eight-Year-Old Girl Killed in Atlanta To Be Laid to Rest; Apple Wins Tax Battle With European Union; Burger King Debuts Eco-Friendly Whopper; President Trump ends special treatment for Hong Kong; Moderna vaccine shows promise, enters final phase; Tuberville easily beats Sessions in Alabama Senate runoff; Ronny Jackson wins Texas Congressional runoff; Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg resting comfortably, recovering from possible infection; Vaccine hopes fueling Futures; Traders weigh bank earnings and spiking virus cases; Expediting infrastructure, President Trump set to announce policy change later today; Merit-based immigration: President Trump vows executive action after DACA upheld by court. Aired 6-6:30a ETLou Dobbs, Maria Bartiromo, Jackie DeAngelis, Cheryl Casone

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS HOST: Facebook, follow me on Instagram, @LouDobbsTonight. We thank you for being us. And good night from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Good morning, everyone. Happy Wednesday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us. It is Wednesday, July 15th. Finally, tax day. Your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

No more special status for Hong Kong. President Trump signing an executive order to punish China over Beijing's crack-down on Hong Kong.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Their freedom has been taken away, their rights have been taken away, and with it goes Hong Kong in my opinion because it will no longer be able to compete with free markets.

I also signed an executive order ending U.S. preferential treatment for Hong Kong. Hong Kong will now be treated the same as Mainland China.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And now, China is threatening even more retaliation. We've got the latest.

Markets this morning pointing to a rally at the start of trading. Upbeat news on Moderna's coronavirus vaccine driving the action this morning. Dow Industrials up 215 points. As you see, the NASDAQ is up 31 and the S&P up 17. This on top of a rally on Wall Street yesterday, the major indices finishing near the session highs at 4 o'clock on Wall Street, with the Dow Industrials up 556 point, the NASDAQ up 97, and the S&P up 42.

A new COVID warning, though, for expectant mothers, as a baby contracts the virus in the womb. Everything you need to know, coming up.

A big win for Apple this morning. A European Union court rules in favor of the technology giant over a multibillion-dollar antitrust tax bill. The stock is up on the news, up 1.25 percent. And the earnings season rolls on this morning. Goldman Sachs among the big banks reporting today, along with the Dow component UnitedHealth. All the numbers (inaudible) hit the tape.

Mornings with Maria is live right now.

And European markets like the investor sentiment of vaccine trials here at home, London also posting better than expected core consumer price data. Look at the European indices right now, with the FT 100 up 51, the CAC quarante in Paris up 63, and the DAX Index in Germany up 122.

In Asia overnight, a mixed story. Take a look. Asian indices finishing like this overnight, with the Shanghai Composite down 1.5 percent although Japan was up one-and-two-thirds percent on the NIKKEI average. The others fractionally moving.

Some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, right now. President Trump turning up turning up the heat on China. The President signed a bill that imposes sanctions on Beijing after China passed a new national security law aimed at crushing descent in Hong Kong. The measure sanctions Chinese officials who crack down on Hong Kong residents.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Their freedom has been taken away, their rights have been take away, and with it goes Hong Kong in my opinion because it will no longer be able to compete with free markets.

I also signed an executive order ending preferential treatment for Hong Kong. Hong Kong will now be treated the same as Mainland China.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: China is vowing to retaliate against the United States with sanctions of its own saying no foreign country has the right to interfere in Hong Kong's affairs.

Well, the U.S. is now one step closer to a vaccine for COVID-19. A vaccine developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna shows all 45 trial participants developed antibodies during a study. The final phase of testing will include 30,000 volunteers. Moderna stock is soaring on the news. It comes as coronavirus cases surge in Los Angeles. The city reporting a new daily high of more than 4,200 infections yesterday alone.

Shocking data in Florida after a local Fox affiliate learned some labs in the state are not reporting negative COVID-19 tests, making the positive rate much higher. The Florida Department of Health releasing a statement saying, it, quote, "began working with those labs to ensure that all results were being reported in order to provide comprehensive and transparent data." The state also broke another record for the most COVID- 19 deaths in one day, 133.

President Trump praising Tommy Tuberville today and Ronny Jackson for winning their respective runoff elections yesterday. Tuberville, the former Auburn football coach, easily beating Former Attorney General Jeff Sessions in Alabama last night. He will now face Democratic Senator Doug Jones in a closely watched race. Meanwhile, Jackson, the Former White House doctor, beating out Josh Winegarner in Texas's 13 House district. He's now the favorite to fill the seat of retiring Congressman Mac Thornberry.

Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg resting comfortably this morning at John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, recovering from a possible infection. Ginsburg was initially evaluated at a D.C. hospital after suffering fever and chills. A spokeswoman says Ginsburg will be hospitalized for a few days. The 87-year-old Justice was hospitalized in May with an infection caused by a gallstone.

JetBlue extending a plan to block the middle seat throughout the summer, meanwhile. The airline says middle seats on its larger planes and aisle seats on smaller planes will not be sold until at least September 8th. But groups of three people can sit - to ask to sit together in the same row. JetBlue's move part of the company's safety from the ground up program amid the COVID-19 pandemic. JetBlue shares this morning are up better than 4 percent in the premarket.

And vaccine hopes pushing Futures higher this morning. Moderna says its coronavirus vaccine produced antibodies in every patient during an early trial, raising hopes for a quicker economic recovery. The stock is on fire. It's up another 16 percent this morning.

Meanwhile, the Dow Industrials posted gains for a third straight session, its largest one-day gain this month. Joining me now is Northwestern Mutual Health Management Chief Investment Strategist, Brent Schutte. Also joining the conversation this morning is The Hill Media Reporter Joe Concha, Fox Business's Jackie DeAngelis, and PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle.

Great to see everybody this morning. Thank you so much for being here.

Brent, let me kick it off with you. Your reaction to what we're learning on the vaccine news with Moderna. Is that what's going to dictate this market's moves until we get the vaccine underway?

BRENT SCHUTTE, NORTHWESTERN MUTUAL HEALTH MANAGEMENT: Yes. I think so. I mean, if you think about the coronavirus, anything that ends its impact or at least decreases its impact in the economy and the markets is a positive. And so if you have a vaccine, you have a treatment, it certainly shrinks the length that we have to live with this in some way, shape or form.

And so that is absolutely a positive to the markets, as is the Fed and other central banks. Plus, you have to also acknowledge that while cases are rising in certain parts of the country, they aren't in others. And we're probably not going back to a nationwide lockdown, which really drove those economic depths that we saw in March.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I want to get your take on what the banks said yesterday. They're all raising money for the effects of this shutdown that they are going to see loan losses. Earning season in full swing. You've got UnitedHealth just reporting a few moments ago. We will also hear from big banks, including Goldman Sachs, Bank of New York Mellon, PNC Financial, and U.S. Bancorp.

This week is a big one. But what are you expecting there after what we've learned from JPMorgan and Citi this week? They are raising money with these expectations that we're going to see increasing loan losses. Does that mean they think the recession gets worse?

SCHUTTE: Yes. I think it's typical behavior. And it's actually what they do during these time periods. I think when you get to that peak provisioning, which hopefully is sometime in the not-too-distant-future, I think you'll start eventually seeing share purchases, and banks right now trade at pretty low level of valuation.

And so, if and when we do get a vaccine or a treatment, if and when the coronavirus loses some of its impact on the economy, we do think looking for that banks are the type of areas of the market that are more cyclical and will benefit from the upside of the economy actually we'll have at that point.

BARTIROMO: I see. Mitch Roschelle, jump in here.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Yes. And I'm interested in, Brent, to see beyond the banks, what your thoughts are in this earning season, because right now, there's sort of an absence of guidance. And I'm curious beyond the Fed and beyond news on vaccines, what are investors going to be looking for in this earning season that could influence the markets?

SCHUTTE: Sure. So, I guess to me, I'm more of a macro person. And so I do think the overall macro, the virus news, the vaccine news, the Fed news kind of controls the overall tone of the market in the way it moves. Earnings are more of a relative barometer.

And so, for example, if a cyclical company comes out and reports that earnings but they're able to survive and their future is still full of cash and all kinds of things that keep them alive, if you get a virus - or I'm sorry - a vaccine, I think the cyclical stocks will still move higher. And so I don't want to downplay earnings.

Certainly I do think that given the economic recovery we've had that we underestimated or at least some people did, I think it's likely that earnings beat expectations. But I still think the overall macro narrative is controlled more by what happens with the virus moving forward.

BARTIROMO: Right. Of course. We need the confidence to get people out there and get revenue generated in a number of these industries.

Jackie DeAngelis, jump in.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, Maria. Great to see you guys.

Brent, I'm wondering what you think about the wave of bankruptcies. We've seen them start to trickle in. But if you think that this is going to be a longer term trend as a result of the pandemic and how that impacts the economy as we move forward, it's something that's sort of keeping me up at night.

SCHUTTE: Yes. And this question comes up quite a bit. And one of the areas of the market we actually like is small caps, where certainly there could be some bankruptcies. And I think during every economic recession, there are bankruptcies, but overall, if you see the virus (inaudible), and I hate to keep coming back to this, but it's really what drove our downturn and our response to it. So we actually did the more nationwide pullback, which caused the economic debts to be so large.

If you see that receding, I do think those more cyclical areas of the economy even with bankruptcy will outperform because the survivors - if you think of what happens during a recession, the weak hands are forced out. The companies that survive are left to garner the higher profits that result in that until you get a new round of competition, which drives earnings down to the cost of capital and then essentially you have the whole cycle repeat.

And so I wouldn't overly fix it on bankruptcy. I would more think about what happens on the other side of this. And at some point, the virus will stop exerting a huge impact on the economy. We'll push forward in more cyclical areas of the market. Even with those bankruptcies, we'll likely outperform because they haven't done so well in the past few years, and that's actually where the value is in the market.

BARTIROMO: OK. So then that's where you're allocating capital, I assume.

Joe Concha, jump in.

JOE CONCHA, THE HILL MEDIA REPORTER: Just a quick question there, Brent. The Dow closed above 26,700. That's above the 2,019 average, which was a great year for the stock market, which was 26,380. And we're probably going to go above 27,000 today if the Futures are any indication.

So, are you surprised that we are where we are in the markets right now, given everything the country has endured economically over the last four months?

SCHUTTE: Yes, I'm a bit surprised of the move lately because the virus - the cases have increased, which I thought might temper the market optimism a bit. But as Maria opened up with the Moderna vaccine news, I think that's actually a positive.

If you're a money manager right now and your underweight equities are behind on your fund, there is a lot of cash in the sideline waiting to come in, and I think that's a buy that dips-type opportunities. So anytime the market falls, these individuals are playing catch-up because they didn't believe that March 23rd was bottom.

That all being said, I guess it's kind of the bifurcation in the markets. So you have the defenses, which is largely the S&P 500 because it is controlled by big-tech stocks who help us do the things that we're doing right now. So they're not really impacted by the virus. And then you have the others. The more cyclical asset classes like small caps, mid caps, and the more cyclical companies that have been punished more.

So I think when people talk about the disconnect between the economy and the markets, you have to kind of look under the sheets and see what's actually happening. And I think that's where the market is reflecting what's happening in the economy. And so I do still, I guess, think there is opportunity in those areas that haven't done as well to do better in the future, just given the fact that they are more economically sensitive. And we do (inaudible) into this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Makes a lot of sense. Great analysis, Brent. Great to see you this morning. Thank you so much, sir.

Brent Schutte--

SCHUTTE: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: --joining us this morning.

On markets and investing today, as we watch this market now at the highs (inaudible) up 269 points on the Dow Industrials.

We're just getting started this morning. Coming up this hour, Georgia Congressman Buddy Carter is here to talk about the President's new plans to help America's infrastructure. Then the Founder of the Atlas Organization, Jonathan Ward, reacting to China's response to the U.S.'s new sanctions over Hong Kong.

A warning for all expectant mothers this morning, the first case emerges of a baby contracting COVID-19 in the womb. Everything you need to know, coming up.

And the streaming wars this morning. We take a look at what NBC is offering with Peacock and the rise in spending on content. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Rebuilding America, infrastructure front and center this morning, as President Trump will travel to Atlanta today. He's expected to announce a policy change focused on fast-tracking projects across the country.

Joining me right now is Georgia Congressman, House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Buddy Carter, who will be at the President's side today.

Congressman, it is good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us about the kind of projects you'd like to get fired up across the country and what the policy might do to do just that.

REP. BUDDY CARTER (R-GA): Well, there's certainly not a better example than what the President is going to be highlighting today, and that is the expansion of lanes on I-75 between Atlanta and Macon. Listen, that's going to help us in South Georgia and the district that I represent, the first Congressional district. We happened to have the second busiest container port on the eastern seaboard in Savannah. And this will enhance freight mobility and help us to get our products, both to the port and from the port, to where they are trying to go.

There's a UPS site right there, and that'll help decrease the amount of - decrease the certainly the congestion there and certainly increase and expedite this project to where we can get it finished. And we will see an increase in the amount of traffic there without having to see the congestion.

BARTIROMO: Well, how important is deregulating some of these situations, whether it's Atlanta or anywhere else in the country? Is the regulatory environment too burdensome that pushes some of these projects to happen and take place over years and years? I mean, there's certain executives who tell me they don't want to invest in any of this because it takes too long.

CARTER: Well, there's no question about it, and there's no better example than the expansion of the Savannah Harbor in the first Congressional district, perhaps the most studied project ever in the history of man. We started that project in the mid-'90s and didn't have construction start until 2015. What we are going to be doing and what the President has done by modifying and adjusting the National Environmental Policy Act is to expedite the process.

BARTIROMO: Right.

CARTER: I think it's erroneous to think that the amount of time you spend reviewing a project equates to the quality of the review. You can review a project in two years and have as good a quality as you can have in seven years. And that's what we've done here and what the President has done. This is truly someone who understands commerce and who understands business.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And the regulatory bite (ph). Let me ask you about Joe Biden, though, because the presumptive Democratic nominee has also unveiled a $2 trillion climate change plan yesterday. The Former Vice President calling for more investment and a shorter timeframe for change. President Trump fired back. Listen to this. Got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I know the climate change is a challenge. It's going to define our American future. I know meeting the challenge would be a once in a lifetime opportunity to jolt new life into our economy, strengthen our global leadership, protect our planet for future generations. And if I have the honor of being elected president, we're not just going to tinker around the edges.

TRUMP: He wants to impose massive energy taxes and job-crushing mandates to eliminate carbon from the United States economy. Let him define the word carbon because he won't be able to. Obliterating American oil, clean coal, natural gas, and the natural energy resources that supply - supply countless American jobs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Congressman, your reaction to what you heard from Biden and, of course, the President's response.

CARTER: Well, I think the President is spot on here. I served on the select committee for climate change, and I can tell you, I don't think that we haven't gotten the credit in the United States for decreasing carbon emissions like we have. We've decreased carbon emissions in this country while growing our economy. And it can be done. There is no question about that.

Look, we all care about the environment. Republicans care about the environment just as much as Democrats do. But we have done a great job of decreasing our carbon footprint at the same time increasing our economy and making sure that our economy continues to grow. And that can be done, and it can be done by the innovations that exist right here in the United States of America.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. We certainly have seen the corporate sector step up in terms of all of this, for sure.

Congressman, it's good to see you this morning.

CARTER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Buddy Carter, we'll be watching your trip to Atlanta with the President this morning.

Coming up, President Trump takes action on immigration. He plans to change the process to enter the United States. We'll tell you all the details.

And then America's fittest cities, find out if your town made the list.

You're watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Merit-based immigration. President Trump promising executive action to bring in high-skilled workers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We are going to take care of DACA because I'm going to be doing in the not-too-distant-future, pretty soon I'm going to be signing a new immigration action, very, very big merit-based immigration action that based on the DACA decision I'll be able to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Now, the DACA decision the President refers to is the Supreme Court's action last month upholding the program for young undocumented immigrants. Chief Justice John Roberts writing in the five-four decision that the administration failed to give adequate justification for rescinding the program.

Joe Concha, what do you think of this next executive action and what might that look like?

CONCHA: Well, it's very interesting what I hear the reaction in the media as far as the President announcing merit-based action yesterday, some accusing him again of the most tired term now in the last three years of him being a racist.

When you look at, however, other countries - OK? In other words, in this country, only 12 percent of legal immigrants are selected based on skill, based on merit. OK? But if you go to, say, Canada or New Zealand or Australia, that number is closer to 60 or 70 percent. So this is a thing that has precedent. It has context in terms of those other countries. And it works in those countries. And I think the President should push that argument more when talking about this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I - I mean, he said that's going to happen in the next - in the near-term. So maybe it's weeks away.

Mitch Roschelle, your reaction.

ROSCHELLE: No, I think this is an important issue. And unfortunately, I think it underscores the unwillingness of Congress to work with the administration. I think everybody agrees that we need to reform our immigration policy, to Joe's point, to make it more realistic with the rest of the world. But again, this is one of the situations where Congress refuses to give the President a win, especially in this area because it takes away their narrative.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it certainly does stop getting things done, doesn't it? This constant fighting.

We'll take a break. When we come back, confronting China, President Trump takes action over Beijing's takeover of Hong Kong and the overreach that the Communist Party has been doing. We're going to tell you what he's doing, coming up.

And then Apple's tax victory. The technology giant wins a major case against the European Union this morning. How much it's saving? Next up, right here.

MARIA BARTIROMO, ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Well, welcome back, good Wednesday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us. It is Wednesday, July 15th, and let's take a look at market this morning, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast, and we are looking at a rally underway. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading, we've got upbeat news this morning on Moderna's coronavirus vaccine that is driving the action.

Dow Industrials right now at the highest of the morning, up better than 300 points, that's better than 1 percent, the Nasdaq is up 58 and the S&P 500 right now up 29. This on top of the big rally yesterday on Wall Street. The major indices finishing near session highs with the Dow Industrials up 556 points at the close yesterday on the Dow Industrials, that was 2 percent. The Nasdaq was up 97 and the S&P was up 42.

European markets also rising on the vaccine news this morning out of Moderna. Take a look. FTSE 100 up 73 points. In the U.K., consumer prices edging higher-than-expected last month, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up 85 and the Dax index in Germany up 165 points, one and a third percent there as well. In Asia overnight, more than mixed performance. The Bank of Japan lowering its growth forecast but keeping interest rates where they are on hold, the Nikkei average up 1.5 percent overnight.

The Shanghai Composite in China down 1.5 percent overnight. Meanwhile, the 8-year-old girl killed in Atlanta will be laid to rest today. Cheryl Casone with the details now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, Maria, good morning. Secoriea Turner was shot and killed while sitting in her mother's car on the 4th of July. There's now a $50,000 reward for information leading to an arrest in this case. Turner was killed near the Wendy's where Rayshard Brooks died during a confrontation with police last month. That restaurant has now been demolished.

Well, a major legal victory for Apple to tell you about. Breaking news this morning. The European Union's second highest court says the company does not have to pay $15 billion in back taxes to Ireland. Court ruled the EU failed to prove Apple was granted in legal subsidy. The European Commission can still appeal the ruling to Europe's highest court, but this decision comes as the EU is weighing a possible digital services tax on America's big-tech companies.

Taking a look at Apple in the pre-market, stock is up almost 2 percent right now, 394.83 cents on that stock. Finally, here is a look at what's trending this morning on foxbusiness.com. Today is the tax-filing deadline, and some Americans may have no choice but to file a paper return due to a glitch in the system related to the coronavirus stimulus checks. Well, despite warnings issued by the federal government, tens of thousands of Americans may have thrown out their $1,200 stimulus payments, they might have mistaken them for junk mail.

And finally, Burger King has debut a whopper made from cows on a plant-base diet. They cut down on methane emissions that impact climate change. And those are your headlines from here, Maria, back over to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you so much. Meanwhile, U.S.-China trade tensions, President Trump doubling down on his hard-line stance against China, signing a legislation and an executive order to hold China and the Communist Party accountable for their crack-down on Hong Kong's freedoms, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This law gives my administration powerful new tools to hold responsible the individuals and the entities involved in extinguishing Hong Kong's freedom. We've all watched what happened, not a good situation, their freedoms have been taken away, their rights have been taken away, and with it goes Hong Kong in my opinion because it will no longer be able to compete with free markets.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the founder of the Atlas Organization, he is the author of "China's Vision of Victory", Dr. Jonathan Ward. Jonathan, good to see you this morning, thank you so much for being here. First, let me get your take on the U.S.' response. We know that China says it's going to retaliate, but how significant do you see this in terms of sanctions on individuals behind the Hong Kong crack-down?

JONATHAN WARD, FOUNDER, ATLAS ORGANIZATION: I think this is incredibly important -- good morning, Maria. I mean, you've seen sanctions imposed both on Chinese officials that are committing human rights atrocities in Xinjiang, and now those that are enacting the crack-down in Hong Kong. So as China pushes on multiple fronts and does, you know, takes action around its region, we're pushing back. So this is a pretty important move.

And I think there's something also buried in the executive order that's even more important. And what that is, is that the president invokes the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, and this is an act that we all should be paying a lot of attention because it's really the key to strategic competition with China. It gives the president a great deal of power to alter and change the economic relationship and do all kinds of things in the bilateral relationship that you put pressure on China.

So the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, they're going to hear that again, but that was invoked multiple times yesterday.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's talk about that, and how that plays out because the U.S. has released a position on the maritime claims in the South China Sea. This is also important the U.S. champion to free and open Indo-Pacific, today they strengthen U.S. policy in a contentious part of the reason. That's the South China Sea where China and the Communist Party has been militarizing that area, correct?

WARD: Right, and we've just -- the State Department has rejected all of China's claims to the South China Sea as unlawful, which is a big step. Again, I mean, the South China Sea is really only the beginning of China's maritime ambitions. They're using it as a springboard to go across the West Pacific, across the Indian Ocean into the South Pacific and to build -- you know, at this point, they've built one of the largest, you know, maritime fleets there is.

They're building about massive blue water Navy, so we're finally taking action against China. I think that's what you're starting to see, particularly in the last few months as coronavirus provides an extra impetuous to push back on this regime.

BARTIROMO: Now, I know that China has said that they will retaliate already. We know that they've sanctioned GOP Senators, Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, after the U.S. accused them of the human rights issues because of the Uyghurs, the treatments of the Muslims who are -- who are locked up in camps. Is this the kind of -- is this the kind of response you would expect from China? What will be the retaliation coming from China? They say they are sanctioning Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz. What does that mean getting sanctioned by the CCP? They can't go there?

WARD: Things of that nature. I mean, the idea -- yes, that they wouldn't really be able to travel to China, those sorts of things. But I don't think that really has any practical effect. It's really posturing, I mean, at this point, they're in a war of words with the United States and they're doing their best to show that they can take reciprocal action. I think the other thing we should be more concerned about is where they do actually have points of leverage, and there have been Chinese speeches that haven't made it into English, that talk about the role of our company.

So, our Fortune 500 that has spent, you know ,a decade building into the China market. There's one speech that talked about how China held a soft under-belly of America in its hands through companies like General Motors and Apple, you know, Ford and Starbucks, they're all over there. So I think we're going to start to see them, you know, they still think that our business executives are levered to push back against U.S. policy when they've tried that before where they bring executives over and try and tell them that they have to go back to Washington and try to de-escalate things.

So I think we're going to see that kind of thing coming as well as other sort of symbolic acts against American officials.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan, and then there's Huawei, we know what the U.S.' stance is against Huawei, but now the U.K. has reversed its stance on Huawei. The U.K. banning the Chinese technology giant from its 5G telecom network, all existing Huawei equipment must be removed by 2027 -- I don't know, 2027, Jonathan, I mean, that's how long they're giving for the -- to remove the Huawei infrastructure. Is it too little, too late?

WARD: That's a long way off, but it's still a bill that can be improved, and there's a big difference from where Britain was, you know, just a couple of years ago, warranting a golden decade with China. So I think you're seeing a massive -- a strategic shift taking place in the United Kingdom and they're coming back to the special relationship with the United States. And I think they're part of a much broader coalition that can ultimately defeat the People's Republic of China.

You know, and if you look at what's happening in India in the past month, what's happening in Australia and Japan, Japan just released a new defense white paper, I mean, these are the democracies that can ultimately come together to cut back our economic dependence on China, begin to box them in. And finally, come up with a winning grand strategy that unites the Democratic field. You know, this is the biggest problem of our time, and in China, the Communist Party in China, these are the bad guys and we're going to have to defeat them.

So that's going to take working with our allies and everything from 5G to collective defense to, you know, new trade relationships. So, we have to -- you know, that picture, I think is starting to --

BARTIROMO: And you think -- and you think we have the allies on this. Because the U.S. probably can't do this alone, take on China, we need allies across the world to do that. And we've seen a string of various speeches, we've heard from Secretary Pompeo, we've heard from now Christopher Wray; head of the FBI, we've heard from Robert O'Brien; NSA, and we're all feeling like what's coming out of these speeches is a new affront against corporations.

American corporations who are looking to sell their wages to the 1.4 billion people in China. Do you think companies are getting it, that the national security issues are paramount and priority for all of these leaders. This administration versus making money by selling products to China when you're not getting a fair shake.

WARD: Well, I think the business relationship with China is -- you know, has peaked at this point, and that all has to be revised, and we do need CEOs and boards to start taking this seriously, and realize that we have a genuine national security problem. I mean, this is the biggest long-term threat to both our security and prosperity, and you know, those that prioritize prosperity over security will have neither in the end to, you know, paraphrase Ben Franklin, let's say that. You know, bottom line, we're going to have to rethink --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

WARD: The economic relationship. It's already happening. But we need the CEOs on board, that's the next big step because otherwise, you have this big conflict between U.S. National Security and U.S. business. We can't have that conflict. We need to be on the same side.

BARTIROMO: By the way, Jonathan, several U.S. subsidiaries of Chinese companies actually received COVID-19 PPP loans according to the Treasury. One company named in a Department of Defense list affirms connected to the Chinese military. So, these are Chinese companies that have U.S. subsidiaries and they got PPP money, your reaction.

WARD: I think that's money that the taxpayers should have back. You know, there's going to be a broader look as well --

BARTIROMO: I see, so --

WARD: The role of the -- companies here. I mean, the ICC, the potential to hold the ICC standards, I mean, this economic relationship, the entanglement of our two economies, you know, frankly was a big strategic mistake. So, we're going to have to look at how that gets, you know, separated over time, and I think there's going to be some decisive action and then there will be some slower things. But bottom line, I mean, it's an economic relationship that's been very deep, and yet it creates the strategic dilemma where at the end of the day we lose our position in the world, we lose our security and ultimately our prosperity if we continue.

BARTIROMO: Wow, Jonathan, it's great to get your insights on this subject as always, thank you, sir. Jonathan D.T. Ward joining us this morning on China. We'll see you soon, Jonathan. Coming up, Ghislaine Maxwell behind bars, a judge making a key decision in the case of Jeffrey Epstein's long- time confidant. We'll take a look when we come right back. Then Covid-19's pregnancy risk, what expectant mothers need to know -- you're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, bail was denied. A judge ordered Jeffrey Epstein's long-time confidant Ghislaine Maxwell to prison, on charges she facilitated the sexual abuse of young girls. The judge saying that the British socialite poses an extreme flight risk because of her financial resources, she got $20 million apparently, international ties and, quote, "extraordinary capacity to avoid detection".

Maxwell pleaded not guilty, her trial expected to begin next July. Joining me right now is Fox News legal analyst and defense attorney Mercedes Colwin. Mercedes, thanks very much for being here. Your reaction, do you believe Ghislaine will be in jail until the trial next July?

MERCEDES COLWIN, FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST: I do, Maria, great to be on with you. It's so -- when you look at the facts -- first of all, the judge got it right. The judge said she has -- she's extreme wealth, the charges are very significant, she faces 35 years in prison if convicted. The fact that she had been basically alluding authorities for over a year purchased a multiple-million-dollar home in New Hampshire under blind trust in an alias.

When the authorities went to the New Hampshire home, they found lots of passports, obviously there was cash on hand. So there were so many signs that if she were released, she would be a flight risk.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. So apparently, she's got like $20 million --

COLWIN: Right --

BARTIROMO: Over several different bank accounts, and she's got 3 passports, is that right?

COLWIN: Exactly right.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

COLWIN: So, one of the things --

BARTIROMO: OK --

COLWIN: And once you added it all up --

BARTIROMO: So --

COLWIN: Judge Nathan just thought it was too much of a risk.

BARTIROMO: Yes, prosecutors detailing what they call serious red flags concerning Maxwell's deception, even telling a real estate agent that she was a journalist named Janet Marshal, so she's got the alias going, that's for sure.

COLWIN: Exactly. And frankly, because she's such a treasure trove of information, the prosecutors want to put as much conceivable pressure on her, so that she will start identifying others that were involved, which frankly, it's like who is who of the most powerful men in the world.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. Let's bring Jackie DeAngelis, go ahead, Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, CNBC REPORTER: And Mercedes, you know, I find this part of the story is so interesting, perhaps even more so than what Jeffrey Epstein himself did because she's being painted as the mastermind here. But your last point is where I'm really intrigued because she does not seem like the type of person that is going to make it in jail. Is this where she starts to say, OK, here is who was involved and starts to deflect the attention away from herself because she is not used to living this kind of lifestyle?

COLWIN: Oh, it's exactly right, Jackie. I mean, there's also concerns, her lawyers apparently raised the concern of COVID-19. There had been a number of individuals that were stricken, and that was one of the reasons also. They had said that she was at risk of contracting the disease as well. So frankly, given that, the fact that this is so different than the lifestyle she's led -- and really, the prosecutor's main goal, with all these, there's going to be all this back-channel communication with her lawyers is to get as much conceivable information and evidence, and have Ghislaine Maxwell give that information to the prosecutors.

I'm sure at this point they do have a list of individuals, at least, suspects that they'd like to really bring to justice, and keeping her in prison will certainly get her there --

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, are we going to -- are we going to actually get to this? So that's what we thought we were going to get, that treasure trove with Jeffrey Epstein, and then he, quote, unquote, "committed suicide". Is that her fate as well?

COLWIN: Maria, I think that everyone is pretty concerned. As I have said before, the biggest challenge the prosecutors face is keeping her alive because she -- with her is all that intellectual capital of others that were involved in the sex-trafficking of these young girls. So, frankly, that's going to be very significant. That's why they've been taking so many measures already. She's wearing paper clothing, she will --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

COLWIN: Be moved from cell to cell, she will be in isolation as well. They're taking as many conceivable precautions to make sure she stays alive for that trial for next Summer.

BARTIROMO: Well, all right, we'll see, Mercedes, great to get your insights this morning, thank you so much. Mercedes Colwin, we'll see you soon.

COLWIN: Great to be on --

BARTIROMO: Thanks --

COLWIN: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, America's fittest cities, the fittest cities, find out if your town made the cut. You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

(MUSIC)

BARTIROMO: Time for the Morning Buzz. First up, ranking America's fitness. The American College of Sports Medicine finding Arlington, Virginia as the fittest city in the country. The list takes into account, healthy behaviors, disease statistics and infrastructure as well. Mitch, what do you think about this?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Fellas really need -- and here's the best part with all of us who have been sheltered in place and working from home and can't go to gyms. A report found that 100 cities, all of them saw improvements in similarities including exercising, less smoking and the number of parks that people could go to, and a gym and a walk. So I think the believe that we're all sitting around eating cheetahs and getting fat was just debunked. We're actually getting a little healthier, which is a good thing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right, getting out and doing some exercise. All right, how about this, a real milestone for "Vanity Fair", the magazine's latest issue features actress Viola Davis marking the first cover shot by a black photographer. Dario Calmese photos have been featured in publications including "The New York Times". Jackie, this is the first cover story shot by a black photographer on "Vanity Fair" ever.

DEANGELIS: Absolutely, and I think it's really, you know, striking as you look at the image there. It's "Vanity Fair" saying that it wants to be part of the conversation about racism, and especially specifically, within the fashion industry, right? Trying to make a statement there. But the article that goes along with it talks about a lot of things. It talks about Davis growing up in poverty. It talks about her life in Hollywood, and she makes comments on participating in the George Floyd protest, and she basically said that her whole life has been a protest.

So, this is the start of a conversation, and not just within a certain realm, but now in the fashion industry as well with a very visual statement here.

BARTIROMO: You're right, and I love Viola Davis, and I love the conversation. I'm just shocked that this is the first time they had a black photographer shoot the cover. I mean --

DEANGELIS: Absolutely --

BARTIROMO: I'm surprised.

DEANGELIS: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Finally, yes, I mean --

DEANGELIS: It is actually --

BARTIROMO: Come on, it's 2020, guys, this is the first time? Finally, you'll never believe it's a cake, a Turkish cake and sugar artist going viral for creating hyper-realistic confections made to look like bananas, shoes, plants, and then other everyday items. Look at these, these are cakes, Joe, what do you think?

JOE CONCHA, MEDIA REPORTER, THE HILL: Well, I think I don't need any more cake options, all right, I mean, the bottom line is that my wife just had - -

BARTIROMO: That's to write another --

CONCHA: Look like I'm in my second trimester. If you -- think of the Stanley Cup. That's me, all right. But would I eat a cake that looks like a dog or a shoe, not exactly something that comes to mind when you're thinking about diving into a nice --

(LAUGHTER)

Carrot cake or something. So -- look, I'm all for it, but I would have to close my eyes and just taste instead of looking, Maria, let's put it that way.

BARTIROMO: I got you, yes, well, you're right, when you put it that way, I guess you're right. Still ahead, the word on Wall Street is coming up, we're getting the insights from some top Wall Street expert as we look at triple-digit gains at the opening of trading, how to allocate your capital, much more ahead next hour right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

urn:contentItem:5WG1-8X01-JDHD-W35S-00000-00Eine Weltwährung;Mit seinem digitalen Finanzsystem Libra startet Facebook einen neuen Angriff auf Demokratie und Freiheit2019-07-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:59ZLexisNexisFeuilletonHintergrundMünchenBayernS. 10Eine WeltwährungMit seinem digitalen Finanzsystem Libra startet Facebook einen neuen Angriff auf Demokratie und FreiheitVON EVGENY MOROZOV

PDF-Datei dieses Dokuments

PDF-Datei dieses Dokuments

Was sollen wir von Facebooks plötzlichem Vorstoß in die Welt des digitalen Geldes halten? Gerade als die Regulierungsbehörden aus ihrem selbstverschuldeten Koma erwachten und begriffen, dass Facebook viel zu schnell viel zu groß geworden ist, hat das Unternehmen beschlossen, sein Engagement für sein Credo vom ,,schnellen Entwickeln und Zerstören' (,,move fast and break things') zu verdoppeln. Die guten alten Zeiten, in denen Facebook lediglich die Privatsphäre Einzelner und die Integrität von Wahlen verletzte, sind vorbei. Und wir werden sie vermissen. Weil sie von der Chance in den Schatten gestellt werden, das globale Finanzsystem zu zerstören.

Zu diesem Zweck hat Facebook gerade Libra angekündigt, eine Währung, eine Infrastruktur, ein Netzwerk - eine diffuses digitales Gebilde, das groß genug ist, um alles für alle zu sein, mit dem ,,Prädikat wertvoll'-Habitus der hehren .org-Domain-Endung. Es ist die ultimative Schrödingers Katze der digitalen Wirtschaft: eine Blockchain/Nicht-Blockchain, sie wird als Geld/Nicht-Geld dienen, um Facebook/uns alle zu retten/zu begraben.

Die Angaben, wie dieses amorphe Projekt mal funktionieren wird, sind noch etwas dürftig. Man kann aber den ungefähren Anspruch erkennen. Es soll den Nutzern - vor allem denen, die dummerweise kein Bankkonto, aber glücklicherweise ein Facebook-Konto haben - ermöglichen, echtes Geld in Libra umzuwandeln, es virtuell einzuzahlen, es an andere zu schicken oder es zur Bezahlung von Dienstleistungen zu nutzen.

Facebook lässt keine Zweifel an seinem humanitären Engagement aufkommen: Libra ist hier, um der Weltbank zu helfen, und nicht, um sie von den verbleibenden Vermögenswerten zu befreien. So gibt es für Uber und Mastercard, die sich Libra als Partner angeschlossen haben, auch gemeinnützige Organisationen wie Mercy Corps und Women"s World Banking, die dem heutigen Finanz- und Digitalkapitalismus ein menschliches, ja sogar ein Smiley-Gesicht verleihen. Ohne dieses gemeinnützige Kontingent würde die Libra-Gesellschaft eher wie ein innovationsfreundliches Verbrechersyndikat aussehen. Ein Blick auf die Gesamtzahl der jüngsten Gerichtsverfahren, an denen Uber, Mastercard und Facebook beteiligt waren, reicht.

Es läge nahe, Facebooks Schritt in den Finanzsektor als weiteren Beweis für ihre unendliche Chuzpe und ihre kurzsichtige Arroganz misszuverstehen. Ist Libra nur eine clevere Art, den wütenden Regulierungsbehörden ins Gesicht zu spucken? Woher nimmt Facebook den Mut zu verkünden, dass sie mit der Politik zusammenarbeiten werden, um das regulatorische Umfeld für ihre Bedürfnisse ,,zu gestalten'? Kein vernünftiger Regulator wird wollen, dass es so aussieht, als ob er von jemandem aus dem Umkreis von Facebook beeinflusst wird.

Facebook ist jedoch kein Neuling in Sachen Kontroversen und wahrscheinlich weniger naiv, als es das Libra-Manifest vermuten lässt. Sheryl Sandberg, Zuckerbergs Stellvertreterin, ist mit der Finanzwelt bestens vertraut. Sie arbeitete früher mal unter Larry Summers im US-Finanzministerium. Könnte es sein, dass Mark Zuckerberg tatsächlich einen Plan hat? Trotz der ersten Eindrücke verfolgt Facebook eine riskante, aber rationale Doppelstrategie. Erstens muss das Unternehmen sein Geschäft dringend diversifizieren, weg von der Werbung. Zweitens wollen sie so weit wie möglich einige der strengeren Regulierungsmaßnahmen verhindern, die wahrscheinlich auftauchen werden, wenn der Wahlkampf um die US-Präsidentschaft in diesem Jahr anläuft.

Das Diversifikationsstück ist unkompliziert: Die chinesischen Wettbewerber von Facebook haben bereits gezeigt, dass Zahlungen und Kommunikation einen sehr profitablen Mix ergeben. Außerdem werden die Kontolosen der Welt nicht für immer so bleiben. So wie die Dinge jetzt stehen, werden sie höchstwahrscheinlich von Chinas Technologieriesen bedient, da Peking die digitalen Komponenten seiner globalen Strategie ,,One Belt, One Road' erweitert. Ohne eine starke Präsenz bei Zahlungsdiensten wäre Facebook nicht in der Lage, es mit Tencent oder Alibaba auf ausländischen Märkten aufzunehmen.

Andererseits steht Facebook durch die direkte Übernahme der chinesischen Konkurrenten in der Gunst von Donald Trump: Ein Facebook, das aggressiv versucht, die globale Expansion chinesischer Unternehmen zu untergraben, ist für Washington ein wichtigerer strategischer Vorteil als das pazifistische Facebook von gestern. Im Moment ist eine weitere Intensivierung des Kalten Tech-Krieges nur eine gute Nachricht für Facebook, da solch eine erhitzte Rhetorik (und Praxis) die Bemühungen Washingtons, ihn zu beenden, lähmen würde.

Aber es gibt noch andere Gründe für das Vorgehen von Facebook. Bei der Vorbereitung auf den Kampf um seine Zukunft scheint das Unternehmen begriffen zu haben, dass seine beste Waffe die ist, genau die Art von Populismus zu mobilisieren, die es bereits anderen Silicon-Valley-Giganten - insbesondere Uber und Airbnb - ermöglicht hat, ihre Nutzer für ihre Anti-Regulierungs-Kampagnen zu gewinnen.

Indem sie ihre Firma als Rebellentruppe gegen mittelmäßige Bürokraten und träge Unternehmensgründer positionieren, versuchen die Strategen von Facebook, die Öffentlichkeit davon zu überzeugen, dass ihr Unternehmen, die emanzipatorische Kraft der universellen Störung, nur ein Opfer der globalen Verschwörung durch kranke Politiker und faule Konkurrenten ist. Angesichts der grenzenlosen öffentlichen Feindseligkeit gegenüber Banken und ihren Regulierungsbehörden - die nur noch von der Feindseligkeit gegenüber den Telekommunikationsunternehmen übertroffen wird - könnten solche Argumente sogar überzeugend klingen.

Mit der Einführung von Libra könnte Facebook (wenn auch nur subtil) bestätigen, dass sich sein Geschäftsmodell bald ändern wird. Bemerkenswert ist, dass es bereits die Idee aufgegriffen hat - einst ein Gräuel in den Kreisen von Big Tech -, dass Benutzerdaten eine Ware mit einem Preisschild an der Spitze sind. So hat Facebook kürzlich eine App auf den Markt gebracht, die Nutzer dafür bezahlt, Daten darüber zu sammeln, wie es mit Diensten und Anwendungen seiner Mitbewerber interagieren. Aber was ist mit dem Wert der Daten, die die Nutzer generieren, während sie selbst Facebook nutzen?

Die langfristige Wette von Facebook könnte sehr wohl darin bestehen, dass eine digitale Wirtschaft, in der Daten und digitale Dienste vollständig kommerzialisiert werden, genauso profitabel sein könnte wie diejenige, in der die Erfordernisse der Werbung dazu beitragen, diese Daten unverfälscht zu halten. Ja, Facebook müsste seinen Nutzern etwas zahlen. Andererseits könnte es ihnen auch ihre Dienste in Rechnung stellen. Solange alle derartigen Transaktionen in einer Währung unter ihrer impliziten Kontrolle durchgeführt werden - und wenn es Facebook gelingt, seine Nutzer davon zu überzeugen, dass seine Daten allein weit weniger wert sind als die von ihnen erbrachten Dienstleistungen - wäre es nicht unbedingt ein so schlechtes Ergebnis. Tatsächlich ist das mit ziemlicher Sicherheit besser als die Aussicht, das Unternehmen aus kartellrechtlichen Gründen in kleinere Stücke zu zerlegen.

Wenn Facebook bereit ist, eine solche scheinbar radikale Umstellung auf Zahlungen und Abonnements vorzunehmen, würde es viele seiner Kritiker entwaffnen, die darauf bestanden haben, dass der Grund, Facebook zu fürchten, gerade darin besteht, dass es zu süchtig nach Werbung ist und andere Modelle nicht annehmen kann. Aber wäre ein anderes Facebook - ein Champion der digitalen Währungen - weniger bedrohlich?

Vielleicht haben die Kritiker die Art der Bedrohung missverstanden. Facebook, zusammen mitAmazon, Alphabet und einigen anderen, ist ein Problem, das sich grundlegend von dem anderer Branchen unterscheidet. Solange sie mit Daten handeln und solange Daten das Lebenselixier von Demokratie und Wirtschaft bleiben, werden diese Unternehmen einen unverhältnismäßigen und unangemessenen Einfluss auf Entscheidungen ausüben, die in Parlamenten und nicht auf Marktplätzen getroffen werden sollten. Ob sie es durch Extrahieren unserer Daten und dem Anzeigen von Werbung oder durch Kaufen unserer Daten und Verkaufen ihrer Dienstleistungen ausüben können, ist nicht so wichtig. Ein Geschäftsmodell, so profitabel es auch sein mag, ist nie eine solide Grundlage für eine stabile Demokratie. Dafür haben wir Verfassungen.

urn:contentItem:60G1-BKD1-JBN9-72XV-00000-00Eine Woche der Wahrheit für die Tech-Konzerne2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:59ZLexisNexisWIRTSCHAFTEine Woche der Wahrheit für die Tech-KonzerneChristof Leisinger, New York

Apple, Amazon, Facebook und Google müssen vor dem US-Kongress den Vorwurf entkräften, dass sie sich wie Monopolisten verhalten

Christof Leisinger, New York

Im Technologiebereich steht eine Woche der Wahrheit bevor. Erstens legen Apple, Amazon, Facebook und Google in den nächsten Tagen ihre Umsatz- und Ertragszahlen für das vergangene «Corona-Quartal» vor. Zweitens steht eine Anhörung vor dem Antitrust-Unterausschuss des amerikanischen Kongresses an, in der sich die Chefs der genannten Unternehmen kritischen Fragen über ihr strategisches Verhalten stellen müssen.

Eine Menge kritischer Fragen

Bei Apple zum Beispiel dürfte es so wie bei ähnlichen Diskussionen in Europa unter anderem um die hohen Gebühren gehen, die das Unternehmen in seinem App-Store von Entwicklern für den Kontakt zu den iPhone-Besitzern verlangt. Google und Facebook werden Fragen beantworten müssen, die ihre starke Marktstellung bei der Suche im Internet anbelangen, bei der Vermittlung von sozialen Kontakten und vor allem auch was die ungefilterte, gezielte Platzierung politisch sensitiver Werbebotschaften angeht, während bei Amazon dessen aggressive Wachstumsstrategie auf Unbehagen stösst.

Natürlich wehren sich die Unternehmen nach Kräften gegen entsprechende Vorwürfe und gegen die Kritik an ihren dauerhaft hohen Margen, die bei echtem Wettbewerb eigentlich schon lange unter Druck hätten geraten müssen. Die Konzerne haben dank ihrer unheimlichen Finanzkraft eine Armee von Lobbyisten engagiert, die manchmal ziemlich obskure Wege wählen. So tragen sie gemäss Informationen der «New York Times» unter anderem zur Finanzierung des Global Antitrust Institute der George Mason University bei. Fragt sich nur, welchen Einfluss dieses dann bei Veranstaltungen in luxuriösem Umfeld nimmt, zu denen Regulatoren aus aller Welt eingeladen werden, und zu welchem Ergebnis Studien über die wirtschaftliche Bedeutung digitaler Plattformen wohl kommen mögen.

Wie auch immer - die operativen Ergebnisse der Internetriesen für das vergangene Quartal werden wohl ziemlich schwach ausfallen. Bei Apple geht der Markt von einem Gewinnrückgang je Aktie um 6,4% aus, bei Facebook und Google von einem solchen um jeweils gut 20% und bei Amazon sogar von einem Rückgang um gut 70%. Im Gegensatz zum robust wachsenden Mitbewerber Microsoft spüren sie die Folgen der wirtschaftlichen Flaute in den vergangenen drei Monaten, die bei Google und Facebook kurzfristig zu deutlich sinkenden Werbeeinnahmen geführt hat, während Amazon einen Kostenschub und Apple einen Umsatzdämpfer verarbeiten müssen.

Die Anleger scheint das nicht zu schrecken. Offensichtlich gehen sie von vorübergehenden Ertragsdellen und längerfristig robusten Wachstumsmöglichkeiten aus und haben in den vergangenen Wochen die Kurse der Papiere deutlich nach oben getrieben. Die Aktien von Amazon zum Beispiel haben seit Jahresanfang trotz vorübergehenden «Corona-Turbulenzen» um bis zu 72% zugelegt, jene von Apple um bis zu 35% und die von Facebook sowie Google um gut 20%. Die enormen Unterschiede sind auf die unterschiedlichen Geschäftsmodelle zurückzuführen. Tatsächlich sind Google und Facebook praktisch ausschliesslich von Werbeeinnahmen abhängig, die in konjunkturellen Krisen regelmässig deutlich unter Druck geraten. Sie erwirtschaften zudem einen beachtlichen Anteil der Erlöse in den USA, wo die Corona-Krise aufgrund der inkonsequenten Eindämmung zu einem Dauerproblem zu werden droht.

Hat die Anhörung Biss?

Sollten sie regulatorisch wegen des intransparenten Umgangs mit den Daten ihrer Nutzer unter Druck geraten, müssten ihre Geschäftsmodelle aufgrund der bisher nicht gelungenen operativen Diversifikation skeptischer betrachtet werden. Allerdings scheint die Gefahr im Moment nicht allzu gross zu sein. Denn «Big Tech hat gewonnen, bevor die Anhörung begonnen hat», argumentiert Professor Scott Galloway von der New York University Stern School of Business sarkastisch. Das Arrangement, alle vier Unternehmenschefs gleichzeitig aussagen zu lassen, und das auch noch virtuell, hemme die Fähigkeit des Komitees, sachlich in die Tiefe zu gehen und etwas zum Vorschein zu bringen, was nicht schon bekannt wäre, fürchtet er.

Die meisten Beobachter tun solche Veranstaltungen als «viel Lärm um nichts» ab und gehen davon aus, dass grosse Unternehmen nicht einfach nur deswegen zerschlagen werden können, weil sie eben gross sind. Schon am Beispiel des «Monopol-Streitfalls» bei Microsoft Ende der neunziger Jahre hat sich gezeigt, wie komplex die Thematik ist. Der Softwareriese aus Seattle ist seitdem jedenfalls kräftig gewachsen, und glaubt man dem Konkurrenten Slack, wendet er heute ähnliche Methoden an wie damals bei Netscape, um kleinere Mitbewerber nicht gross werden zu lassen. Auf der anderen Seite hat Amazon während der Covid-19-Krise so massiv in das weitere Wachstum des E-Commerce investiert, dass Kritiker laut die schwierige Lage der konventionellen Konkurrenten und die starke Marktstellung des Unternehmens beklagen werden.

Allerdings wird nichts so heiss gegessen, wie es gekocht wurde. Nach einer schlagzeilenträchtigen Phase rechnen die meisten Investoren eher mit leicht zu verschmerzenden Geldstrafen als mit einer grundlegenden Änderung der Geschäftsmodelle. Als gesichert gilt dagegen, dass die grossen Internetkonzerne derzeit keine bedeutenden Übernahmen planen, weder wird Giphy von Facebook geschluckt noch Fitbit durch Google. Schliesslich würden sie dadurch nur das Schlaglicht auf sich ziehen und wieder Fragen beantworten müssen.

Kursturbulenzen abzusehen

So dürften die betroffenen Unternehmen in den kommenden Tagen aufgrund der Quartalszahlen und der öffentlichen Anhörung vor dem Unterausschuss des Kongresses zwar Schlagzeilen machen. Und das könnte an der Wall Street zu gewissen Kursturbulenzen führen - allerdings eher weil die Notierungen in den vergangenen Wochen im Vergleich mit der erwarteten Gewinnentwicklung überraschend stark gestiegen und die Titel entsprechend teuer geworden sind als wegen grundlegender Zweifel an der Zukunft der Unternehmen in ihrer gegenwärtigen Struktur.

urn:contentItem:60FT-CDX1-DY4B-Y1JW-00000-00Eine Woche der Wahrheit für die Tech-Konzerne2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:59ZLexisNexisWIRTSCHAFTEine Woche der Wahrheit für die Tech-KonzerneChristof Leisinger, New York

Apple, Amazon, Facebook und Google müssen vor dem US-Kongress den Vorwurf entkräften, dass sie sich wie Monopolisten verhalten

Christof Leisinger, New York

Im Technologiebereich steht eine Woche der Wahrheit bevor. Erstens legen Apple, Amazon, Facebook und Google in den nächsten Tagen ihre Umsatz- und Ertragszahlen für das vergangene «Corona-Quartal» vor. Zweitens steht eine Anhörung vor dem Antitrust-Unterausschuss des amerikanischen Kongresses an, in der sich die Chefs der genannten Unternehmen kritischen Fragen über ihr strategisches Verhalten stellen müssen.

Eine Menge kritischer Fragen

Bei Apple zum Beispiel dürfte es so wie bei ähnlichen Diskussionen in Europa unter anderem um die hohen Gebühren gehen, die das Unternehmen in seinem App-Store von Entwicklern für den Kontakt zu den iPhone-Besitzern verlangt. Google und Facebook werden Fragen beantworten müssen, die ihre starke Marktstellung bei der Suche im Internet anbelangen, bei der Vermittlung von sozialen Kontakten und vor allem auch was die ungefilterte, gezielte Platzierung politisch sensitiver Werbebotschaften angeht, während bei Amazon dessen aggressive Wachstumsstrategie auf Unbehagen stösst.

Natürlich wehren sich die Unternehmen nach Kräften gegen entsprechende Vorwürfe und gegen die Kritik an ihren dauerhaft hohen Margen, die bei echtem Wettbewerb eigentlich schon lange unter Druck hätten geraten müssen. Die Konzerne haben dank ihrer unheimlichen Finanzkraft eine Armee von Lobbyisten engagiert, die manchmal ziemlich obskure Wege wählen. So tragen sie gemäss Informationen der «New York Times» unter anderem zur Finanzierung des Global Antitrust Institute der George Mason University bei. Fragt sich nur, welchen Einfluss dieses dann bei Veranstaltungen in luxuriösem Umfeld nimmt, zu denen Regulatoren aus aller Welt eingeladen werden, und zu welchem Ergebnis Studien über die wirtschaftliche Bedeutung digitaler Plattformen wohl kommen mögen.

Wie auch immer - die operativen Ergebnisse der Internetriesen für das vergangene Quartal werden wohl ziemlich schwach ausfallen. Bei Apple geht der Markt von einem Gewinnrückgang je Aktie um 6,4% aus, bei Facebook und Google von einem solchen um jeweils gut 20% und bei Amazon sogar von einem Rückgang um gut 70%. Im Gegensatz zum robust wachsenden Mitbewerber Microsoft spüren sie die Folgen der wirtschaftlichen Flaute in den vergangenen drei Monaten, die bei Google und Facebook kurzfristig zu deutlich sinkenden Werbeeinnahmen geführt hat, während Amazon einen Kostenschub und Apple einen Umsatzdämpfer verarbeiten müssen.

Die Anleger scheint das nicht zu schrecken. Offensichtlich gehen sie von vorübergehenden Ertragsdellen und längerfristig robusten Wachstumsmöglichkeiten aus und haben in den vergangenen Wochen die Kurse der Papiere deutlich nach oben getrieben. Die Aktien von Amazon zum Beispiel haben seit Jahresanfang trotz vorübergehenden «Corona-Turbulenzen» um bis zu 72% zugelegt, jene von Apple um bis zu 35% und die von Facebook sowie Google um gut 20%. Die enormen Unterschiede sind auf die unterschiedlichen Geschäftsmodelle zurückzuführen. Tatsächlich sind Google und Facebook praktisch ausschliesslich von Werbeeinnahmen abhängig, die in konjunkturellen Krisen regelmässig deutlich unter Druck geraten. Sie erwirtschaften zudem einen beachtlichen Anteil der Erlöse in den USA, wo die Corona-Krise aufgrund der inkonsequenten Eindämmung zu einem Dauerproblem zu werden droht.

Hat die Anhörung Biss?

Sollten sie regulatorisch wegen des intransparenten Umgangs mit den Daten ihrer Nutzer unter Druck geraten, müssten ihre Geschäftsmodelle aufgrund der bisher nicht gelungenen operativen Diversifikation skeptischer betrachtet werden. Allerdings scheint die Gefahr im Moment nicht allzu gross zu sein. Denn «Big Tech hat gewonnen, bevor die Anhörung begonnen hat», argumentiert Professor Scott Galloway von der New York University Stern School of Business sarkastisch. Das Arrangement, alle vier Unternehmenschefs gleichzeitig aussagen zu lassen, und das auch noch virtuell, hemme die Fähigkeit des Komitees, sachlich in die Tiefe zu gehen und etwas zum Vorschein zu bringen, was nicht schon bekannt wäre, fürchtet er.

Die meisten Beobachter tun solche Veranstaltungen als «viel Lärm um nichts» ab und gehen davon aus, dass grosse Unternehmen nicht einfach nur deswegen zerschlagen werden können, weil sie eben gross sind. Schon am Beispiel des «Monopol-Streitfalls» bei Microsoft Ende der neunziger Jahre hat sich gezeigt, wie komplex die Thematik ist. Der Softwareriese aus Seattle ist seitdem jedenfalls kräftig gewachsen, und glaubt man dem Konkurrenten Slack, wendet er heute ähnliche Methoden an wie damals bei Netscape, um kleinere Mitbewerber nicht gross werden zu lassen. Auf der anderen Seite hat Amazon während der Covid-19-Krise so massiv in das weitere Wachstum des E-Commerce investiert, dass Kritiker laut die schwierige Lage der konventionellen Konkurrenten und die starke Marktstellung des Unternehmens beklagen werden.

Allerdings wird nichts so heiss gegessen, wie es gekocht wurde. Nach einer schlagzeilenträchtigen Phase rechnen die meisten Investoren eher mit leicht zu verschmerzenden Geldstrafen als mit einer grundlegenden Änderung der Geschäftsmodelle. Als gesichert gilt dagegen, dass die grossen Internetkonzerne derzeit keine bedeutenden Übernahmen planen, weder wird Giphy von Facebook geschluckt noch Fitbit durch Google. Schliesslich würden sie dadurch nur das Schlaglicht auf sich ziehen und wieder Fragen beantworten müssen.

Kursturbulenzen abzusehen

So dürften die betroffenen Unternehmen in den kommenden Tagen aufgrund der Quartalszahlen und der öffentlichen Anhörung vor dem Unterausschuss des Kongresses zwar Schlagzeilen machen. Und das könnte an der Wall Street zu gewissen Kursturbulenzen führen - allerdings eher weil die Notierungen in den vergangenen Wochen im Vergleich mit der erwarteten Gewinnentwicklung überraschend stark gestiegen und die Titel entsprechend teuer geworden sind als wegen grundlegender Zweifel an der Zukunft der Unternehmen in ihrer gegenwärtigen Struktur.
